comment_text.mn39:1.2: Assapura, the “horse fort”, appears to be unknown apart from its mention here and the next sutta. Contra Dictionary of Pali Proper Names, this is not the same Assapura referred to in Ja 422, as that lay south of Ceti, far to the west. An Aśvapura is mentioned in Jain legends, but there is nothing to link this with the Aṅgan town. | Aṅga lay to the east of Magadha on the Ganges, towards modern Bengal.
comment_text.mn39:2.2: This sutta deals with the difference between outer perception and inner reality, addressing what we call “imposter syndrome”. The Buddha inspires students to aspire to the highest ideal through the practice of the Gradual Training so that they live up to their labels and claims.
comment_text.mn39:4.2: Chiddavā (“inconsistent”) is more literally “full of holes”. Its opposite (acchidda) is one of the standard descriptors of “impeccable” precepts (eg. MN 48:6.12). | Saṁvuta (past participle of saṁvara) can mean either “restrained” or “hidden, secretive”. The sense depends on the syntax; the two instances of ca split the listed items into three plus two, with the negative distributed over the last two items. This agrees with the commentary, which explains “secretive” as “concealing one’s faults”. Saṁvara appears in the sense of sense restraint below (MN 39:8.4).
comment_text.mn39:14.1: The similes for the hindrances and jhānas feature also in DN 2:69.1 and DN 10:2.7.1.
comment_text.mn39:15.3: As a meditator proceeds, their subjective experience of the “body” evolves from tactile sense impressions (phoṭṭhabba), to the interior mental experience of bliss and light (manomayakāya), to the direct personal realization of highest truth (MN 70:23.2: kāyena ceva paramasaccaṁ sacchikaroti).
comment_text.mn39:15.4: The kneading is the “placing the mind and keeping it connected”, the water is bliss, while the lack of leaking speaks to the contained interiority of the experience.
comment_text.mn39:16.3: The simile emphasizes the water as bliss, while the lack of inflow expresses containment and unification. The water welling up is the rapture, which is the uplifting emotional response to the experience of bliss.
comment_text.mn39:17.3: The meditator is utterly immersed in stillness and bliss.
comment_text.mn39:18.3: The white cloth is the purity and brightness of equanimity. The commentary explains this as a person who has just got out of a bath and sits perfectly dry and content.
comment_text.mn39:22.1: This series of epithets is also found at AN 7.85–92, split over separate suttas, and with other terms and explanations in Snp 3.6. The explanations here rely on puns, the feel of which I have tried to echo in English.
comment_text.mn39:23.1: Samaṇa (“ascetic”) is from a root meaning to exert or weary oneself, but here is explained as if related to samita (“assuaged”, “calmed”).
comment_text.mn39:24.1: The root sense of brah- is to “amplify” or “empower”, but is explained as bāhita (“banished”, “expelled”). This is a common play on words, eg. Ud 1.4:4.1, Dhp 388:1.
comment_text.mn39:25.1: A nhātaka (Sanskrit snātaka) is one who has performed the ritual ablutions on the completion of his studies.
comment_text.mn39:26.1: The “knowledge” in vedagū is the Vedas in Brahmanism and the three knowledges in Buddhism. Curiously, it is not an attested term in Brahmanical texts. Perhaps it arose by contraction from Sanskrit vedapāraga, or such passages as (tiṇṇaṁ) vedānaṁ pāragū.
comment_text.mn39:27.1: Sottiya (“scholar”) is from the root “to hear”, as is the more familiar Pali term sāvaka (“disciple”, “student”, literally “hearkener”). In Brahmanism śrotrīya refers to one who is well versed in the Vedas. Here, however, it is connected with the root su (“to flow”), as in one who has “rinsed off” or “scoured off” bad things.
comment_text.mn39:28.1: Both ariya and arahant are explained with the same word āraka, meaning “far from (defilements)”. The commentary gives āraka in both cases, but explains ariya as “slayer” and arahant as “far from”. At AN 7.91, PTS has arīhatattā, “foe-slayer” for ariya (BJT omits, while at least one more variant is attested). This is a slightly better pun for ariya than āraka, although at Snp 3.6:38.1 ariya is punned with ālaya (“clinging”), which is better than both. Where both MA 182 and the parallel to MN 40 at MA 183 at T i 726c13 mention the ariya, the Indic pun underlying EA 49.8 seems to be that a kṣatriya is so called because they “end” (Sanskit kṣaya) the defilements. Neither of the Chinese parallels (MA 182 at T i 725c4, EA 49.8 at T ii 802b4) mentions the arahant, suggesting it was added later, which would explain the duplication of āraka. However, given that “far from” is consistently attested for the arahant in all editions and commentary; that “foe-slayer” is attested for ariya in some texts and commentaries; and that kṣatriya in the sense of “warrior” is loosely in the same semantic realm as “foe-slayer”, I translate accordingly.
comment_text.mn39:29.1: Arahant (“perfected one”) has the root sense “worthy” and in Buddhism has the sense of one who has perfectly or “impeccably” removed all defilements.

root_text.mn39:3.2: ‘Hirottappena samannāgatā bhavissāmā’ti evañhi vo, bhikkhave, sikkhitabbaṁ.

root_text.mn39:8.10: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ manindriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ, tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjissāma, rakkhissāma manindriyaṁ, manindriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjissāmā’ti evañhi vo, bhikkhave, sikkhitabbaṁ.

root_text.mn39:9.2: ‘Bhojane mattaññuno bhavissāma, paṭisaṅkhā yoniso āhāraṁ āharissāma,

root_text.mn39:10.2: ‘Jāgariyaṁ anuyuttā bhavissāma, divasaṁ caṅkamena nisajjāya āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi cittaṁ parisodhessāma.
root_text.mn39:10.3: Rattiyā paṭhamaṁ yāmaṁ caṅkamena nisajjāya āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi cittaṁ parisodhessāma.
root_text.mn39:10.4: Rattiyā majjhimaṁ yāmaṁ dakkhiṇena passena sīhaseyyaṁ kappessāma pāde pādaṁ accādhāya, sato sampajāno uṭṭhānasaññaṁ manasi karitvā.
root_text.mn39:10.5: Rattiyā pacchimaṁ yāmaṁ paccuṭṭhāya caṅkamena nisajjāya āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi cittaṁ parisodhessāmā’ti, evañhi vo, bhikkhave, sikkhitabbaṁ.
root_text.mn39:10.6: Siyā kho pana, bhikkhave, tumhākaṁ evamassa:
root_text.mn39:10.7: ‘hirottappenamha samannāgatā, parisuddho no kāyasamācāro, parisuddho vacīsamācāro, parisuddho manosamācāro, parisuddho ājīvo, indriyesumha guttadvārā, bhojane mattaññuno, jāgariyaṁ anuyuttā;

root_text.mn39:11.2: ‘Satisampajaññena samannāgatā bhavissāma, abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī, ālokite vilokite sampajānakārī, samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe sampajānakārī, asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī, uccārapassāvakamme sampajānakārī, gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī’ti, evañhi vo, bhikkhave, sikkhitabbaṁ.
root_text.mn39:11.3: Siyā kho pana, bhikkhave, tumhākaṁ evamassa:
root_text.mn39:11.4: ‘hirottappenamha samannāgatā, parisuddho no kāyasamācāro, parisuddho vacīsamācāro, parisuddho manosamācāro, parisuddho ājīvo, indriyesumha guttadvārā, bhojane mattaññuno, jāgariyaṁ anuyuttā, satisampajaññena samannāgatā;
root_text.mn39:11.5: alamettāvatā katamettāvatā, anuppatto no sāmaññattho, natthi no kiñci uttariṁ karaṇīyan’ti tāvatakeneva tuṭṭhiṁ āpajjeyyātha.

root_text.mn39:14.1: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso iṇaṁ ādāya kammante payojeyya.
root_text.mn39:14.3: So yāni ca porāṇāni iṇamūlāni tāni ca byantī kareyya, siyā cassa uttariṁ avasiṭṭhaṁ dārabharaṇāya.
root_text.mn39:14.5: ‘ahaṁ kho pubbe iṇaṁ ādāya kammante payojesiṁ, tassa me te kammantā samijjhiṁsu.
root_text.mn39:14.6: Sohaṁ yāni ca porāṇāni iṇamūlāni tāni ca byantī akāsiṁ, atthi ca me uttariṁ avasiṭṭhaṁ dārabharaṇāyā’ti.
root_text.mn39:14.7: So tatonidānaṁ labhetha pāmojjaṁ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṁ.
root_text.mn39:14.8: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso ābādhiko assa dukkhito bāḷhagilāno, bhattañcassa nacchādeyya, na cassa kāye balamattā.
root_text.mn39:14.9: So aparena samayena tamhā ābādhā mucceyya, bhattañcassa chādeyya, siyā cassa kāye balamattā.
root_text.mn39:14.11: ‘ahaṁ kho pubbe ābādhiko ahosiṁ dukkhito bāḷhagilāno, bhattañca me nacchādesi, na ca me āsi kāye balamattā, somhi etarahi tamhā ābādhā mutto, bhattañca me chādeti, atthi ca me kāye balamattā’ti.
root_text.mn39:14.12: So tatonidānaṁ labhetha pāmojjaṁ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṁ.
root_text.mn39:14.13: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso bandhanāgāre baddho assa.
root_text.mn39:14.14: So aparena samayena tamhā bandhanā mucceyya sotthinā abbhayena, na cassa kiñci bhogānaṁ vayo.
root_text.mn39:14.16: ‘ahaṁ kho pubbe bandhanāgāre baddho ahosiṁ, somhi etarahi tamhā bandhanā mutto, sotthinā abbhayena, natthi ca me kiñci bhogānaṁ vayo’ti.
root_text.mn39:14.17: So tatonidānaṁ labhetha pāmojjaṁ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṁ.
root_text.mn39:14.18: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso dāso assa anattādhīno parādhīno na yenakāmaṅgamo.
root_text.mn39:14.19: So aparena samayena tamhā dāsabyā mucceyya attādhīno aparādhīno bhujisso yenakāmaṅgamo.
root_text.mn39:14.21: ‘ahaṁ kho pubbe dāso ahosiṁ anattādhīno parādhīno na yenakāmaṅgamo, somhi etarahi tamhā dāsabyā mutto attādhīno aparādhīno bhujisso yenakāmaṅgamo’ti.
root_text.mn39:14.22: So tatonidānaṁ labhetha pāmojjaṁ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṁ.
root_text.mn39:14.23: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso sadhano sabhogo kantāraddhānamaggaṁ paṭipajjeyya.
root_text.mn39:14.24: So aparena samayena tamhā kantārā nitthareyya sotthinā abbhayena, na cassa kiñci bhogānaṁ vayo.
root_text.mn39:14.26: ‘ahaṁ kho pubbe sadhano sabhogo kantāraddhānamaggaṁ paṭipajjiṁ.
root_text.mn39:14.27: Somhi etarahi tamhā kantārā nitthiṇṇo sotthinā abbhayena, natthi ca me kiñci bhogānaṁ vayo’ti.
root_text.mn39:14.28: So tatonidānaṁ labhetha pāmojjaṁ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṁ.
root_text.mn39:14.29: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yathā iṇaṁ yathā rogaṁ yathā bandhanāgāraṁ yathā dāsabyaṁ yathā kantāraddhānamaggaṁ, ime pañca nīvaraṇe appahīne attani samanupassati.
root_text.mn39:14.30: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, āṇaṇyaṁ yathā ārogyaṁ yathā bandhanāmokkhaṁ yathā bhujissaṁ yathā khemantabhūmiṁ; evameva bhikkhu ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahīne attani samanupassati.
root_text.mn39:15.1: So ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe,
root_text.mn39:15.2: vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi, savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn39:15.3: So imameva kāyaṁ vivekajena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa vivekajena pītisukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
root_text.mn39:15.4: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dakkho nhāpako vā nhāpakantevāsī vā kaṁsathāle nhānīyacuṇṇāni ākiritvā udakena paripphosakaṁ paripphosakaṁ sanneyya. Sāyaṁ nhānīyapiṇḍi snehānugatā snehaparetā santarabāhirā, phuṭā snehena na ca pagghariṇī.
root_text.mn39:15.5: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ vivekajena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa vivekajena pītisukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
root_text.mn39:16.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn39:16.2: So imameva kāyaṁ samādhijena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa samādhijena pītisukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
root_text.mn39:16.3: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, udakarahado ubbhidodako. Tassa nevassa puratthimāya disāya udakassa āyamukhaṁ, na pacchimāya disāya udakassa āyamukhaṁ, na uttarāya disāya udakassa āyamukhaṁ, na dakkhiṇāya disāya udakassa āyamukhaṁ, devo ca na kālena kālaṁ sammādhāraṁ anuppaveccheyya. Atha kho tamhāva udakarahadā sītā vāridhārā ubbhijjitvā tameva udakarahadaṁ sītena vārinā abhisandeyya parisandeyya paripūreyya paripphareyya, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato udakarahadassa sītena vārinā apphuṭaṁ assa.
root_text.mn39:16.4: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ samādhijena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa samādhijena pītisukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
root_text.mn39:17.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati, sato ca sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṁvedeti, yaṁ taṁ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn39:17.2: So imameva kāyaṁ nippītikena sukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa nippītikena sukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
root_text.mn39:17.3: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, uppaliniyaṁ vā paduminiyaṁ vā puṇḍarīkiniyaṁ vā appekaccāni uppalāni vā padumāni vā puṇḍarīkāni vā udake jātāni udake saṁvaḍḍhāni udakānuggatāni antonimuggaposīni, tāni yāva caggā yāva ca mūlā sītena vārinā abhisannāni parisannāni paripūrāni paripphuṭāni, nāssa kiñci sabbāvataṁ uppalānaṁ vā padumānaṁ vā puṇḍarīkānaṁ vā sītena vārinā apphuṭaṁ assa.
root_text.mn39:17.4: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ nippītikena sukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa nippītikena sukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
root_text.mn39:18.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā, adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn39:18.2: So imameva kāyaṁ parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena pharitvā nisinno hoti, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
root_text.mn39:18.3: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso odātena vatthena sasīsaṁ pārupetvā nisinno assa, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa odātena vatthena apphuṭaṁ assa.
root_text.mn39:18.4: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena pharitvā nisinno hoti, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
root_text.mn39:19.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn39:19.2: So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ, dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.
root_text.mn39:19.3: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso sakamhā gāmā aññaṁ gāmaṁ gaccheyya, tamhāpi gāmā aññaṁ gāmaṁ gaccheyya, so tamhā gāmā sakaṁyeva gāmaṁ paccāgaccheyya. Tassa evamassa: ‘ahaṁ kho sakamhā gāmā amuṁ gāmaṁ agacchiṁ, tatrapi evaṁ aṭṭhāsiṁ evaṁ nisīdiṁ evaṁ abhāsiṁ evaṁ tuṇhī ahosiṁ; tamhāpi gāmā amuṁ gāmaṁ agacchiṁ, tatrapi evaṁ aṭṭhāsiṁ evaṁ nisīdiṁ evaṁ abhāsiṁ evaṁ tuṇhī ahosiṁ; somhi tamhā gāmā sakaṁyeva gāmaṁ paccāgato’ti.
root_text.mn39:19.4: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.
root_text.mn39:20.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṁ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn39:20.2: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate, yathākammūpage satte pajānāti …pe…
root_text.mn39:20.3: seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dve agārā sadvārā. Tattha cakkhumā puriso majjhe ṭhito passeyya manusse gehaṁ pavisantepi nikkhamantepi, anucaṅkamantepi anuvicarantepi.
root_text.mn39:20.4: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti …pe….
root_text.mn39:21.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn39:21.2: So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
root_text.mn39:21.3: ‘Ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
root_text.mn39:21.4: Tassa evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati.
root_text.mn39:21.6: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
root_text.mn39:21.7: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, pabbatasaṅkhepe udakarahado accho vippasanno anāvilo.
root_text.mn39:21.8: Tattha cakkhumā puriso tīre ṭhito passeyya sippisambukampi sakkharakathalampi macchagumbampi, carantampi tiṭṭhantampi.
root_text.mn39:21.10: ‘ayaṁ kho udakarahado accho vippasanno anāvilo. Tatrime sippisambukāpi sakkharakathalāpi macchagumbāpi carantipi tiṭṭhantipī’ti’.
root_text.mn39:21.11: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti …pe…
root_text.mn39:23.2: Samitāssa honti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, saṅkilesikā, ponobbhavikā, sadarā, dukkhavipākā, āyatiṁ, jātijarāmaraṇiyā.
root_text.mn39:23.3: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu samaṇo hoti.
root_text.mn39:24.2: Bāhitāssa honti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, saṅkilesikā, ponobbhavikā, sadarā, dukkhavipākā, āyatiṁ, jātijarāmaraṇiyā.
root_text.mn39:24.3: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu brāhmaṇo hoti.
root_text.mn39:25.2: Nhātāssa honti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, saṅkilesikā, ponobbhavikā, sadarā, dukkhavipākā, āyatiṁ, jātijarāmaraṇiyā.
root_text.mn39:25.3: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu nhātako hoti.
root_text.mn39:26.2: Viditāssa honti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, saṅkilesikā, ponobbhavikā, sadarā, dukkhavipākā, āyatiṁ, jātijarāmaraṇiyā.
root_text.mn39:26.3: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vedagū hoti.
root_text.mn39:27.2: Nissutāssa honti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, saṅkilesikā, ponobbhavikā, sadarā, dukkhavipākā, āyatiṁ, jātijarāmaraṇiyā.
root_text.mn39:27.3: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sottiyo hoti.
root_text.mn39:28.2: Ārakāssa honti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, saṅkilesikā, ponobbhavikā, sadarā, dukkhavipākā, āyatiṁ, jātijarāmaraṇiyā.
root_text.mn39:28.3: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyo hoti.
root_text.mn39:29.2: Ārakāssa honti pāpakā akusalā dhammā, saṅkilesikā, ponobbhavikā, sadarā, dukkhavipākā, āyatiṁ, jātijarāmaraṇiyā.
root_text.mn39:29.3: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu arahaṁ hotī”ti.
root_text.mn39:29.5: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.

translation_text.mn39:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Aṅgas, near the Aṅgan town named Assapura.
translation_text.mn39:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.mn39:2.2: And when they ask you what you are, you claim to be ascetics.
translation_text.mn39:2.3: Given this label and this claim, you should train like this: ‘We will undertake and follow the things that make one an ascetic and a brahmin. That way our label will be accurate and our claim correct.
translation_text.mn39:2.4: The services of those whose robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick we enjoy shall be very fruitful and beneficial for them. And our going forth will not be wasted, but will be fruitful and fertile.’
translation_text.mn39:3.1: And what are the things that make one an ascetic and a brahmin?
translation_text.mn39:3.2: You should train like this: ‘We will have conscience and prudence.’
translation_text.mn39:3.4: ‘We have conscience and prudence. This is sufficient; enough has been done. We have achieved the goal of life as an ascetic. There is nothing more to do.’ And you might rest content with just that much.
translation_text.mn39:3.5: I declare this to you, mendicants, I announce this to you:
translation_text.mn39:3.6: ‘You who seek to be true ascetics, do not lose sight of the goal of the ascetic life while there is still more to do.’
translation_text.mn39:4.1: What more is there to do?
translation_text.mn39:4.2: You should train like this: ‘Our bodily behavior will be pure, clear, open, neither inconsistent nor secretive.
translation_text.mn39:4.3: And we won’t glorify ourselves or put others down on account of our pure bodily behavior.’
translation_text.mn39:4.5: ‘We have conscience and prudence, and our bodily behavior is pure.
translation_text.mn39:4.7: I declare this to you, mendicants, I announce this to you:
translation_text.mn39:4.8: ‘You who seek to be true ascetics, do not lose sight of the goal of the ascetic life while there is still more to do.’
translation_text.mn39:5.1: What more is there to do?
translation_text.mn39:5.2: You should train like this: ‘Our verbal behavior …
translation_text.mn39:7.2: livelihood will be pure, clear, open, neither inconsistent nor secretive.
translation_text.mn39:7.3: And we won’t glorify ourselves or put others down on account of our pure livelihood.’
translation_text.mn39:7.5: ‘We have conscience and prudence, our bodily, verbal, and mental behavior is pure, and our livelihood is pure.
translation_text.mn39:7.6: This is sufficient; enough has been done. We have achieved the goal of life as an ascetic. There is nothing more to do.’ And you might rest content with just that much.
translation_text.mn39:7.7: I declare this to you, mendicants, I announce this to you:
translation_text.mn39:7.8: ‘You who seek to be true ascetics, do not lose sight of the goal of the ascetic life while there is still more to do.’
translation_text.mn39:8.1: What more is there to do?
translation_text.mn39:8.2: You should train yourselves like this: ‘We will restrain our sense doors.
translation_text.mn39:8.3: When we see a sight with our eyes, we won’t get caught up in the features and details.
translation_text.mn39:8.4: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, we will practice restraint, we will protect the faculty of sight, and we will achieve its restraint.
translation_text.mn39:8.5: When we hear a sound with our ears …
translation_text.mn39:8.6: When we smell an odor with our nose …
translation_text.mn39:8.7: When we taste a flavor with our tongue …
translation_text.mn39:8.8: When we feel a touch with our body …
translation_text.mn39:8.9: When we know an idea with our mind, we won’t get caught up in the features and details.
translation_text.mn39:8.10: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, we will practice restraint, we will protect the faculty of mind, and we will achieve its restraint.’
translation_text.mn39:8.12: ‘We have conscience and prudence, our bodily, verbal, and mental behavior is pure, our livelihood is pure, and our sense doors are restrained.
translation_text.mn39:9.1: What more is there to do?
translation_text.mn39:9.2: You should train yourselves like this: ‘We will not eat too much. We will only eat after reflecting rationally on our food.
translation_text.mn39:9.3: We will eat not for fun, indulgence, adornment, or decoration, but only to sustain this body, to avoid harm, and to support spiritual practice. In this way, we shall put an end to old discomfort and not give rise to new discomfort, and we will have the means to keep going, blamelessness, and a comfortable abiding.’
translation_text.mn39:9.5: ‘We have conscience and prudence, our bodily, verbal, and mental behavior is pure, our livelihood is pure, our sense doors are restrained, and we don’t eat too much.
translation_text.mn39:10.1: What more is there to do?
translation_text.mn39:10.2: You should train yourselves like this: ‘We will be dedicated to wakefulness. When practicing walking and sitting meditation by day, we will purify our mind from obstacles.
translation_text.mn39:10.3: In the first watch of the night, we will continue to practice walking and sitting meditation.
translation_text.mn39:10.4: In the middle watch, we will lie down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware, and focused on the time of getting up.
translation_text.mn39:10.5: In the last watch, we will get up and continue to practice walking and sitting meditation, purifying our mind from obstacles.’
translation_text.mn39:10.7: ‘We have conscience and prudence, our bodily, verbal, and mental behavior is pure, our livelihood is pure, our sense doors are restrained, we don’t eat too much, and we are dedicated to wakefulness.
translation_text.mn39:11.1: What more is there to do?
translation_text.mn39:11.2: You should train yourselves like this: ‘We will have situational awareness and mindfulness. We will act with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.’
translation_text.mn39:11.4: ‘We have conscience and prudence, our bodily, verbal, and mental behavior is pure, our livelihood is pure, our sense doors are restrained, we don’t eat too much, we are dedicated to wakefulness, and we have mindfulness and situational awareness.
translation_text.mn39:12.1: What more is there to do?
translation_text.mn39:12.2: Take a mendicant who frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
translation_text.mn39:13.1: After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged, set their body straight, and establish mindfulness in their presence.
translation_text.mn39:13.2: Giving up covetousness for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of covetousness, cleansing the mind of covetousness.
translation_text.mn39:13.3: Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of sympathy for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will.
translation_text.mn39:13.4: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
translation_text.mn39:13.5: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
translation_text.mn39:13.6: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.
translation_text.mn39:14.1: Suppose a man who has gotten into debt were to apply himself to work,
translation_text.mn39:14.3: He would pay off the original loan and have enough left over to support his partner.
translation_text.mn39:14.7: he’d be filled with joy and happiness.
translation_text.mn39:14.8: Suppose a person was sick, suffering, and gravely ill. They’d lose their appetite and get physically weak.
translation_text.mn39:14.9: But after some time they’d recover from that illness, and regain their appetite and their strength.
translation_text.mn39:14.12: they’d be filled with joy and happiness.
translation_text.mn39:14.13: Suppose a person was imprisoned in a jail.
translation_text.mn39:14.14: But after some time they were released from jail, safe and sound, with no loss of wealth.
translation_text.mn39:14.17: they’d be filled with joy and happiness.
translation_text.mn39:14.18: Suppose a person was a bondservant. They would not be their own master, but indentured to another, unable to go where they wish.
translation_text.mn39:14.19: But after some time they’d be freed from servitude. They would be their own master, not indentured to another, a freeman able to go where they wish.
translation_text.mn39:14.22: they’d be filled with joy and happiness.
translation_text.mn39:14.23: Suppose there was a person with wealth and property who was traveling along a desert road.
translation_text.mn39:14.24: But after some time they crossed over the desert, safe and sound, with no loss of wealth.
translation_text.mn39:14.28: they’d be filled with joy and happiness.
translation_text.mn39:14.29: In the same way, as long as these five hindrances are not given up inside themselves, a mendicant regards them as a debt, a disease, a prison, slavery, and a desert crossing.
translation_text.mn39:14.30: But when these five hindrances are given up inside themselves, a mendicant regards this as freedom from debt, good health, release from prison, emancipation, and a place of sanctuary at last.
translation_text.mn39:15.1: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.
translation_text.mn39:15.2: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn39:15.3: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
translation_text.mn39:15.4: It’s like when a deft bathroom attendant or their apprentice pours bath powder into a bronze dish, sprinkling it little by little with water. They knead it until the ball of bath powder is soaked and saturated with moisture, spread through inside and out; yet no moisture oozes out.
translation_text.mn39:15.5: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
translation_text.mn39:16.1: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn39:16.2: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.
translation_text.mn39:16.3: It’s like a deep lake fed by spring water. There’s no inlet to the east, west, north, or south, and the heavens would not properly bestow showers from time to time. But the stream of cool water welling up in the lake drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads throughout the lake. There’s no part of the lake that’s not spread through with cool water.
translation_text.mn39:16.4: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.
translation_text.mn39:17.1: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
translation_text.mn39:17.2: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with bliss free of rapture. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture.
translation_text.mn39:17.3: It’s like a pool with blue water lilies, or pink or white lotuses. Some of them sprout and grow in the water without rising above it, thriving underwater. From the tip to the root they’re drenched, steeped, filled, and soaked with cool water. There’s no part of them that’s not soaked with cool water.
translation_text.mn39:17.4: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with bliss free of rapture. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture.
translation_text.mn39:18.1: Furthermore, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
translation_text.mn39:18.2: They sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with pure bright mind.
translation_text.mn39:18.3: It’s like someone sitting wrapped from head to foot with white cloth. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread over with white cloth.
translation_text.mn39:18.4: In the same way, they sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with pure bright mind.
translation_text.mn39:19.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives.
translation_text.mn39:19.2: They recollect many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
translation_text.mn39:19.3: Suppose a person was to leave their home village and go to another village. From that village they’d go to yet another village. And from that village they’d return to their home village. They’d think: ‘I went from my home village to another village. There I stood like this, sat like that, spoke like this, or kept silent like that. From that village I went to yet another village. There too I stood like this, sat like that, spoke like this, or kept silent like that. And from that village I returned to my home village.’
translation_text.mn39:19.4: In the same way, a mendicant recollects their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
translation_text.mn39:20.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
translation_text.mn39:20.2: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.
translation_text.mn39:20.3: Suppose there were two houses with doors. A person with clear eyes standing in between them would see humans entering and leaving a house and wandering to and fro.
translation_text.mn39:20.4: In the same way, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.
translation_text.mn39:21.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
translation_text.mn39:21.2: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
translation_text.mn39:21.3: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements.’
translation_text.mn39:21.4: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
translation_text.mn39:21.5: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
translation_text.mn39:21.6: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’
translation_text.mn39:21.7: Suppose that in a mountain glen there was a lake that was transparent, clear, and unclouded. A person with clear eyes standing on the bank would see the clams and mussels, and pebbles and gravel, and schools of fish swimming about or staying still.
translation_text.mn39:21.10: ‘This lake is transparent, clear, and unclouded. And here are the clams and mussels, and pebbles and gravel, and schools of fish swimming about or staying still.’
translation_text.mn39:21.11: In the same way, a mendicant truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
translation_text.mn39:21.12: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’
translation_text.mn39:22.1: This mendicant is one who is called an ‘ascetic’, a ‘brahmin’, a ‘bathed initiate’, a ‘knowledge master’, a ‘scholar’, a ‘noble one’, and also a ‘perfected one’.
translation_text.mn39:23.1: And how is a mendicant an ascetic?
translation_text.mn39:23.2: They have assuaged the bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death.
translation_text.mn39:23.3: That’s how a mendicant is an ascetic.
translation_text.mn39:24.1: And how is a mendicant a brahmin?
translation_text.mn39:24.2: They have banished the bad, unskillful qualities.
translation_text.mn39:24.3: That’s how a mendicant is a brahmin.
translation_text.mn39:25.1: And how is a mendicant a bathed initiate?
translation_text.mn39:25.2: They have bathed off the bad, unskillful qualities.
translation_text.mn39:25.3: That’s how a mendicant is a bathed initiate.
translation_text.mn39:26.1: And how is a mendicant a knowledge master?
translation_text.mn39:26.2: They have known the bad, unskillful qualities.
translation_text.mn39:26.3: That’s how a mendicant is a knowledge master.
translation_text.mn39:27.1: And how is a mendicant a scholar?
translation_text.mn39:27.2: They have scoured off the bad, unskillful qualities.
translation_text.mn39:27.3: That’s how a mendicant is a scholar.
translation_text.mn39:28.1: And how is a mendicant a noble one?
translation_text.mn39:28.2: They have nobbled their foes, the bad, unskillful qualities.
translation_text.mn39:28.3: That’s how a mendicant is a noble one.
translation_text.mn39:29.1: And how is a mendicant a perfected one?
translation_text.mn39:29.2: They are impeccably remote from the bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death.
translation_text.mn39:29.3: That’s how a mendicant is a perfected one.”
translation_text.mn39:29.4: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn39:29.5: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
